headline.main: Where to Start on Geriatric Care
headline.print_headline: Where to Start On Geriatric Care

docs.snippet: Q. How do I know if I need a geriatric care manager?.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sally Porter and her brother, Bill Navran, had two choices. They could either hire home care aides to live with their 79-year-old mother in her condo in Kansas City, Mo., or put her in an assisted living center. The choice could have been straightforward, but for one thing: Mrs. Porter lived in Tucson and Mr. Navran was in Hawaii. The two knew nothing about health care services in Missouri and did not know where to start looking. Luckily, their lawyer knew about Kansas City Home Care, a geriatric care management company that assesses a person's condition and puts together services to address the situation. For $170, a geriatric care manager interviewed their mother, Marjorie Siegel-Navran, for two hours and suggested a way for her to remain at home. They set up four aides, who for $18 an hour would help her bathe, dress, eat and travel.

headline.main: Personal Business; Getting Help for an Aging Relative

docs.abstract: Article on growing importance of geriatric care managers, who help families with aging relatives who want to be taken care of at home; says there are 2,041 certified geriatric care managers, up from 50 when Association of Professional Geriatric Care Managers started in 1986; photo (M)

docs.abstract: Arthur I Lowell letter, prompted by May 30 article about identity theft, says Social Security numbers should not be used to identify Medicare accounts because this puts Medicare patients at risk of identity theft
